subtopics.title: Overview
subtopics.content: This section provides a brief introduction to the basic principles of first aid, including the importance of quick and appropriate action in emergency situations.

subtopics.title: Emergency Situations
subtopics.content: This section outlines the steps to follow in an emergency situation, including how to call for help and how to stay calm and focused.

subtopics.title: Primary Assessment
subtopics.content: This section provides an overview of the primary assessment process, which is used to determine the nature of the injury or illness and the appropriate course of action.

subtopics.title: ABCs of First Aid
subtopics.content: This section explains the importance of the ABCs of first aid, which stands for Airway, Breathing, and Circulation, and provides instructions on how to perform these life-saving techniques.

subtopics.title: Treating Injuries
subtopics.content: This section covers the basics of how to administer first aid for different types of injuries, such as cuts, burns, fractures, and sprains, including how to recognize and respond to each type of injury.

subtopics.content: This section provides an overview of what CPR is and why it is important in emergency situations.

subtopics.content: This section provides step-by-step instructions on how to perform chest compressions and rescue breaths in CPR.

subtopics.title: Using an AED
subtopics.content: This section explains when and how to use an automated external defibrillator (AED) in CPR.

subtopics.title: CPR on Infants and Children
subtopics.content: This section explains how to perform CPR on infants and children, including the differences from adult CPR.

subtopics.title: Recognizing Cardiac Arrest
subtopics.content: This section explains how to recognize the signs of cardiac arrest and how to respond appropriately.

subtopics.title: Seizure and Allergic Reaction

topics.title: How to Treat Burns and Cuts

subtopics.title: Recognizing Burns and Cuts
subtopics.content: Learn to differentiate between first-degree, second-degree, and third-degree burns and how to identify different types of cuts

subtopics.title: Immediate Care
subtopics.content: Understand the immediate care steps to be taken after experiencing a burn or a cut, such as stopping the bleeding, cleaning the wound, and covering it to prevent infection

subtopics.title: Medical Attention
subtopics.content: Know when it is necessary to seek medical attention for burns or cuts and how to find medical help if required

subtopics.title: Preventing Infection and Promoting Healing
subtopics.content: Learn how to prevent infection and promote healing in burns and cuts by using over-the-counter treatments or natural remedies

subtopics.title: Controlling Bleeding
subtopics.content: Discover how to use a tourniquet or apply pressure to control bleeding in serious cuts or wounds

category.name: Self First Aid
category.description: Help yourself when you are alone

subtopics.title: Treating Minor Cuts and Scrapes
subtopics.content: Clean the wound with soap and water, apply an antiseptic, and cover with a bandage.

subtopics.title: Applying Pressure to Stop Bleeding
subtopics.content: Apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage.

subtopics.title: Using a Tourniquet
subtopics.content: Only use a tourniquet as a last resort to stop severe bleeding. Apply it 2-3 inches above the wound, tighten until the bleeding stops, and seek medical help immediately.

subtopics.title: Cleaning and Dressing Wounds
subtopics.content: Clean the wound thoroughly with water and a mild soap, apply an antiseptic ointment, and cover with sterile gauze and tape.

subtopics.title: Identifying Different Types of Burns
subtopics.content: First-degree burns only affect the top layer of skin and appear red and dry. Second-degree burns involve the first and second layers of skin and appear red, blistered, and painful. Third-degree burns are the most severe and involve all layers of skin and the underlying tissue.

subtopics.title: Cooling and Soothing Burned Skin
subtopics.content: Run cool (not cold) water over the burn for several minutes, or apply a cool compress. Use aloe vera, hydrocortisone cream, or an antibiotic ointment to soothe the burn.

subtopics.title: Knowing When to Seek Medical Help
subtopics.content: Seek medical help if the burn is larger than 3 inches, affects the face, hands, feet, or genitals, or if it is a third-degree burn.

subtopics.title: Performing the Heimlich Maneuver on Yourself
subtopics.content: Learn how to perform the Heimlich maneuver on yourself if you are choking and there is no one else around to help you.

subtopics.title: Clearing a Blocked Airway
subtopics.content: Learn how to clear a blocked airway by performing back blows and abdominal thrusts.

subtopics.title: Recognizing the Signs of Suffocation
subtopics.content: Learn how to recognize the signs of suffocation, which can include gasping for air, blue lips or face, and loss of consciousness.

subtopics.title: Avoiding Choking Hazards
subtopics.content: Learn how to avoid choking hazards, such as small toys, foods, and objects that can easily become lodged in the throat.
